abstract.text: A stylized rectangular box with an optional title.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use box objects to visually group the contents of your window. For example, you might use boxes to group related views. Use an
object to configure the appearance of the box.

object is a view that draws a line around its rectangular bounds and that displays a title on or near the line (or might display neither line nor title). You can adjust the style of the line (bezel, grooved, or plain) as well as the placement and font of the title. An
also has a content view to which other views can be added; it thus offers a way for an application to group related views. You could create a custom subclass of

that alters or augments its appearance or that modifies its grouping behavior. For example, you might add color to the lines or background, add a new line style, or have the views in the group automatically snap to an invisible grid when added.
) if you want to customize the appearance of your
objects. Depending on the visual effect you’re trying to achieve, you may have to invoke

‘s implementation first. For example, if you are compositing a small image in a corner of the box, you would invoke the superclass implementation first. If you’re adding a new style of line, you would provide a way to store a request for this line type (such as a boolean instance variable and related accessor methods). Then, in
, if a request for this line type exists, you would draw the entire view yourself (that is, without calling
). Otherwise, you would invoke the superclass implementation.
If you wish to change grouping behavior or other behavioral characteristics of the
If you are drawing the custom
entirely by yourself, and you want it to look exactly like the superclass object (except for your changes), it may take some effort and time to get the details right.

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
A role-based protocol that declares the minimum interface necessary to interact with an assistive app.
The complete list of properties and methods for accessible elements.
A set of methods that defines a way to add animation to an existing class with a minimum of API impact.
A set of methods for getting and setting the appearance attributes of a view.
A stylized rectangular box with an optional title.
These constants and data type identifies box types, which, in conjunction with a box’s border type, define the appearance of the box.
Specify the location of a box’s title with respect to its border.
The color of the receiver’s border when the receiver is a custom box with a simple line border.
The rectangle in which the receiver’s border is drawn.
The receiver’s border type.
The width of the receiver’s border when the receiver is a custom box with a simple line border.
The receiver’s box type.
The receiver’s content view.
The distances between the border and the content view.
The radius of the receiver’s corners when the receiver is a custom box with a simple line border.
The color of the receiver’s background when the receiver is a custom box with a simple line border.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver is transparent.
Places the receiver so its content view lies on the specified frame.
Sets the title of the receiver with a character denoted as an access key.
Resizes and moves the receiver’s content view so it just encloses its subviews.
The receiver’s title.
The cell used to display the receiver’s title.
The font object used to draw the receiver’s title.
A constant representing the title position.
The rectangle in which the receiver’s title is drawn.
A set of methods that the destination object (or recipient) of a dragged image must implement.
Methods that responder subclasses implement to support key binding commands, such as inserting tabs and newlines, or moving the insertion point.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A protocol that marks classes to restore the state of your app to continue a user activity.
A set of methods used to associate a unique identifier with objects in your user interface.
The infrastructure for drawing, printing, and handling events in an app.
Adds a view to the view’s subviews so it’s displayed above its siblings.
Overridden by subclasses to draw the view’s image within the specified rectangle.
A view that adds translucency and vibrancy effects to the views in your interface.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
